title: Improve K8200 Z-Switch
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
To day it is raining so no hunting.
I were really disturbed on the Z-endpoint switch adjustment on my K8200 so it is to day or never.
Had some stuff laying around 200mm M6 rod some M6 nuts, glue, gearlock glue a longer screw to the Z-switch and some matching nuts to it.
Got the idea to K8200 from this guy who had made it for ultimaker.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:208822
Liked his knob as I reused ( inported it to scad it is the file Z_thumbnut.stl so that is not the one you will print).
Feel free to do your version to your printer or improve this one to K8200/3Drag all files included. Sorry for the last picture but it is a bug in thingiverse webspace rotating it.

author: IceDizzy

description.text:
This is a spare/replacement Z stabiliser for the Robo3D. I decided to design my own as I didn't like the currently available designs. I tried to provide better support and strength without using a lot of additional filament.
Drill the stabiliser out to 8mm but start with the smallest drill bit you have that will increase the hole as trying to take too much out in one go is difficult and could result in breaking the stabiliser. Try to drill in short bursts to not heat the plastic up too much. You'll also need to drill out the 4 mounting holes to fit the M3 (3mm) bolts through.
I have not test fit these to my printer yet as I haven't had the need to replace my stock stabilisers. Please comment and add photos if you use these.
Printed in PLA with 4 perimeters. I think my infill was 95%.

comments.text:
Thanks @Knightrider. I'll adjust the base thickness and upload an additional STL, I'll keep the thicker based file as well in case anyone prefers it.
This design is intentionally a bit higher than the stock Z stabiliser for additional support since the center hole needs to be drilled out to fit. The hole is actually designed as 8mm but any over extrusion will obviously reduce its diameter.

comments.text: The only thing that need to be tweaked that isn't that easy to get around is that size of the hole for the guide. And maybe make the base a smidge thinner just to keep from having to buy longer screws. Other then those minor things, It printed out perfect and fits great.

description.text:
Yet another spool clip - this one is designed to be printed in PLA. Because its flexible, it is compatible with MakerBot and 100mm x 30mm spools and most likely many others. UPDATE Jan 22 2013 I have created four different clips sizes to accommodate reels with different flange widths. S = 3.0mm
M = 3.5mm
L = 4.0mm
XL = 4.5mm This clip was designed using an ACIS solid in Shark FX (sfx file included) so will behave well with Makerware, ReplicatorG and skeinforge.

I printed this with my new 340 micron profile which you can download here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:39050 The settings used are really critical to getting this to work. Infill 0%
Layer Height 0.34 mm
Number of shells 0

comments.text: So awesome. With a filament length between .22m for the small and .28m for the XL at 0.2mm layer height, it's a great way to get rid of the last meter or two of remnant filament. Print time time is very fast too, about 8-9 minutes.

Oye! Oye! Brenda the articulated battle tardigrade has been released into the wilds of 3D printing! Join the Horde to be among the first humanoids to learn about the next epic project from Zheng Labs! We now return you to your regular model description.

Shark Tank? Shark Week? Sharknado? Pfah. Finger Shark. If you've ever done a 3D printing demo you've seen a dozen kids get all excited about the technology, watched your printer struggle to burp out a Yoda before the event ends, and then seen dejected kids walk away empty-handed. (A brief note to folks who do 3D printing demos: as of August 2014 there are more 3D printed Yodas in the world than there are children, so you can stop printing them now.) Never again, my friends. Finger Shark is fun, fashionable, and fabricates fast. Print a dozen to chum the waters at your next Maker event. Finger Shark is designed for a size 7 ring, which should snugly fit the fingers of most adults. You'll need to scale all three parts of Finger Shark to fit smaller fingers. To that end, the handy-dandy Zheng3 Ring Sizing PDF will help you teach a little basic algebra while the kids are printing finger sharks. (Another brief note to folks who do 3D printing demos: attempting to teach algebra during a demo may cause kids to shy away from your booth.)

title: Nikon Eyepiece Cap. D5100 and similar models.

description.text:
Made for the D5100 camera. But will probably fit lot's of other Nikons. Just measure the naked viewfinder and if it is 24mm...ish across then this will probably fit.  
These things are just a simple cap to cover the viewfinder to stop ambient light from leaking trough the viewfinder. Good for those long exposures.  
I misplace or lose these all the time. It is just a simple piece of plastic so why fork out money for these when you have a printer?

Just print flat laying down. No raft but with supports. I used 5 layers and 100% fill. This thing uses just a little over a gram of plastic, so no need to save on strength or weight, just make it solid. Use a sharp "x-acto" type knife for trimming away supports and adjusting the fit.

title: Favorite Robots: EVE & WALL-E and ROOMBA

description.text:
The latest in a series of g-code releases of plottable/drawable "favorite robots." 
I, for one, believe there should be more "robot" things in the MakerBot community. Why don't you scan and trace your favorite robots (both of fiction and fact) and share them back with us here?
While these images are for the MakerBot Unicorn Pen Plotter, feel free to adapt them to the Frostruder or other pen plotter tools. I included all of the source files I used so you can make your own versions. There are also better images out there -- I encourage you all to out do me here and post your version!
These are more images requested and prepped for MakerFaire NYC 2010. Behind the Star Wars characters and a few enthusiastic pushes for Keepon, Wall-E and Roomba were the second most frequently requested. For this release I updated my assets with the new dxf conversion I used to create the better speedier prints of R2-D2 and C-3PO also here on Thingiverse.com.

description.text: This is a fan mount for NEMA 17 motors to hold a 40mm fan with hole centres spaced 32mm

Print and attach fan with 3mm tapered screws.
Holds onto motor without further fixtures.
Designed to fit on my y axis although I have a 275mm wide bed so this may not fit on all Meldels due to overall length. Thanks goes to hudbrog for use of his G-code viewer :) This is my first thing nothing special yet functional. Hope you like :)

comments.text: Here is a problem I had though. The motor was getting so hot that I think it was distorting the belt. My prints would shift up by about half a mm.(or more) each layer. Finally I put a fan on a roll of tape pointing at the motor for the deration of my prints and now they seem to print quite well. Is my motor reaching crazy hi temps. like above 70c., are my belts crazy cheap(stock printrbot jr. belts) or are the fans really atually just a good idea? No derission meant this is an actual question.
comments.author: Thugorp

comments.text: I often see fans on stepper motors... Don't be afraid by their temperature: the internal coils can reach 70Â°C without problem. So, the body is hot too. The only issue is it can melt the support, if it is made in PLA. But if not, you can let it heat up...

funny rocket

Stephen C Phillips recently wrote an article on his blog about streaming music from and Android device to a rPi. (http://blog.scphillips.com/2013/01/using-a-raspberry-pi-with-android-phones-for-media-streaming/) His idea was to connect a rPi to an existing HiFi system to stream music. I wanted a slightly more portable version. I had a USB speaker, the Cubite by Boyng, that I no longer used - it was only USB1.1. That has been ripped apart to be remounted into the case. Its only 3W but has reasonable sound quality for what I am looking for. Now I effectively have a portable WiFi streaming speaker that I can use anywhere in the house.

To be honest unless you have a Cubite unit around, or can get one, this won't be of much use. However I have supplied the original SketchUp file so people can play and maybe use it as inspiration for another project. Otherwise:
Print out all 3 skins,
Remove the supports,
Clip in Raspberry Pi,
Screw the speaker board into the front two sections,
Attach the speakers to the back skin,
Screw back skin to top and bottom,
Stream music where you have WiFi!

title: Cello Bridge
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a copy of a wooden cello bridge, but made via 3D printing out of ABS.
To have something to test, I made 2 very similar bridges, but with different in-fill percentages, ~32% and ~55%. Once installed and played, both had almost identical behavior, very good volume, bright sound, but a little "nasal". Will test with a 100% infill to see if the sound improves. Overall, it works well, but not good enough for serious performances.
Here's a brief video where you can hear it in action.
http://youtu.be/VxaruJPKCpU Update: After printing the bridge with a 100% in fill, there was no significant improvement in the sound quality. It still sounds "nasal". At this point, I don't know what I would have to modify to make it sound better.

comments.text: What if you printed with wood imbued filament/carbon fiber filament? I don't know if the wood filament would change anything, but I imagine the carbon fiber (especially ABS not PLA blended with CF) would be much more rigid and have a high tensile strength. It may make the bridge more suited to a fuller rounder tone due to the harmonics that the PLA gobbles up. Just my 2 cents. I'm getting a printer this week, and this is the first print I think I might make! Also, because of the difference in density of materials, it is likely there is much more batting around of the overtones. I would also be interested in playing a wood cello with steel strings, a carbon fiber bow and an ABS/CF bridge. I would also think there might be some benefits to making a different style bridge (e.g. Belgian/French/baroque styles). Oh, and just one more idea... what about making some kind of additional cuts in the bridge to allow for a different density of the bridge or adding long holes to add rods inside the bridge thus increasing the density! :-) Lots to try out here, so I don't think you can count it out in regards to its replacing a wood bridge just yet!
comments.author: stevegw

comments.text:
Steve,
All great ideas. The trouble is that I do not play a cello, nor have access to one any more. You are welcome to try any or all of the variations that you suggest. If you would like my help in any way, all you have to do is ask. I think that the bridge's geometry must change to take into account the resin's sound transmission characteristics. The current shape was developed across years or decades of trial and error by some of the best luthiers after trying all sorts of wood types and geometries. There has to be a better geometry for ABS, PLA, woodfill, and/or carbon fill. There are people developing interesting algorithms that can make almost any shape sound like a tuning fork. I found a thesis from a korean university that studied the shape of violin bridges and how the shape could be altered for specific sound out put. There is plenty of science to be applied here.
comments.author: stevegw

comments.text:
Hi,
Just made it and installed, and, first, huge thanks, my bridge was broken for a year and it makes me want to play cello again.
comments.author: Natalucciu

comments.text:
Hi Natalucciu,
I am honored that you liked the cello bridge. If you want to modify the sound, you might want to try putting a thin layer of leather under the bridge's feet. At least that is advice I received from another cello player. In any case, I am thrilled that you are using it. Let me know if you want to try any changes. David.
comments.author: Natalucciu

comments.text:
I think it's fine like so, at least for me, as I said, I am a pretty bad cellist, plus I played today for the first time in a year, I wasn't good a year ago, I am bad today ! :D
I am sure these details are important for a real cellist but for a begginer like me it's all good ! And as I said, I like this bright sound !
However, I will try the leather "trick".
comments.author: smallnetd

comments.text: How about printing it with PLA? It is much harder than ABS. I guess the ABS plastic is too soft for the task.
comments.author: bubnikv

comments.text: Go right ahead. PLA should hold up just fine. I didn't try other materials just because I couldn't keep testing. The cello was a friend's and the bridge was more like an emergency replacement. I would like to try making one out of wood filled PLA. Let me know if I could help in any way.
comments.author: bubnikv

comments.text: How did you deal with getting the correct slope for the feet of the bridge?
comments.author: svvsdCAD

comments.text: I had the luck of copying the original bridge. I scanned it and gave it the same slope the wooden one had. Once printed, you could put them back to back and the geometries were a perfect match. The sound, however, was not the same. I played with the infill, varying it from about 30% all the way to 100%. At 100% it sounded the best, but still kind of nasal. I still have the parametric model, so I can change a lot of the geometry's features. I haven't had anyone tell me what they would like to change to make it sound better.
comments.author: svvsdCAD

comments.text: What about a thin cork wafer between the sound board and the bridge, maybe a bit of dampening would make the tone more mellow ?
comments.author: TuxSoft

comments.text: Thanks for the suggestion. We'll see.

comments.text:
Favor to ask:
If you make this bridge and play with it, would you please send to me a recording of how it sounds on your cello? If you do record it, please do so by playing the open strings first (then whatever you want) and with at least 22kHz sampling, mono, and with no compression. Thanks.

A version of the Fruit Fly Catcher with a swivel top and a base of it's own so you don't have to use a nasty jar and watch the things fly around all day while they die. YUCK!   
Put a piece of fruit or some apple cider vinegar in the base and the fruit flies get trapped inside. Keep the lid on and submerge it in water to kill the flies and clean it. Easy.

comments.text: It looks to me like the pivot hole in the lid is on the wrong side.  The cones should point down into the cup for this to work.  Fruit flies will fly down into the cones, but when they try to fly out they will first fly to the top-most surface they can find (the roof) then try to crawl up.  Since the cones point down they can't find their way out.  It works more by behavior than by physical trapping, and is surprisingly effective.

title: Mice & Mystics - Large and Small Card Boxes

description.text:
These boxes fit the small and large cards for the board game Mice and Mystics. Each box fits all cards of the appropriate size, regardless of card type -- the large box fits both the Search cards and the Encounter cards, the small box fits both the Initiative cards and the Ability cards. The tolerances between the cards and box are pretty tight, so the tabs don't allow the lid to close. The lids fit nicely onto the bases, so I just broke the tabs off and am happy with the results. The lids don't fall off, yet come off easily; The cards don't have room to move around much, but don't get stuck in the base. Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:137961

Prevents your child from turning on your oven and/or changing the temperature. Snaps right on to the oven handle if your oven looks like mine. Tested successfully on a 12 months old baby.

First find out if this will fit your oven. It should look like the photos attached to this Thing. Also ensure that it never gets hot enough on the outside to melt the plastic you print with. PLA should probably not be used.
  • Open the .scad file in OpenSCAD.
  • Measure your oven and tweak the parameters at the top of the file.
  • From the Design menu, select "Compile and Render (CGAL)" and then "Export as STL".
  • Slice and print the STL with support material enabled.
  • Cut away the support material, which will be under the arch.
  • Open the oven a bit and insert the Thing under the center of the handle. It should snap into place without too much force -- don't use tools.
  • Slide it along the handle to cover the desired dial.

I made this battery holder to make attaching the battery more secure, and to make changing batteries much easier. It works much like a one-piece shaft collar; it fits the battery, and uses friction to hold the battery in place, without causing any damage to the papery skin of the battery. It uses a .25" standoff with screws screwed into it from both sides as a pivot. Make sure to screw in both screws at once, so that there is less stress on the part that holds the standoff. On the other side, there is a nut that is held in place by friction, the lock washer, and the bottom part, and this nut won't come out in normal use (although it can be taken out with an allen, or something similar). The screw that goes into it is held in by friction, so that it won't fall out when the battery holder is opened. It screws into the frame of the robot with two screws at the bottom, which are counterbored so that the heads don't touch the battery.
This went through several revisions, and the three earliest revisions are shown attached to the battery. This was printed on a makerbot 2x in abs, and takes about an hour to print (for both pieces at 15% with 2 (or 3?) shells); make sure to print one of them flipped over and on their side, so that the plastic runs across the battery (this can be seen in the pictures), so that they are even. Don't screw the main screw in too hard, or it may crack the plastic. To adjust the compression of the battery, adjust the "space" parameter in both files (top and bottom), I found that .035" works best. More compression will risk cracking the plastic, less will not hold the battery as securely. The thickness of the material that goes over the battery is .225" (controlled by the "thick" parameter), more thickness is not necessary, that part won't break as is.
This is not competition legal (because it isn't an official vex part... yet), but it can be used in the classroom. Battery mounting is much easier and allows the battery to be mounted in more positions, taking up less space, and allowing better weight distribution.
By the way, these battery holders have been dubbed "Zev Ties" by my electronics teacher, because my name is Zev, I like zip ties, and these are a superior alternative.

3d print on its side (so flow lines are as they are in the pictures), with one side flipped over.  Insert (1) .25" standoff in the back, screw two .5" 8-32 screws into the standoff a the same time.  Insert 8-32 keps nut in the front, insert .5" screw into its hole, this doesn't need to be removed during use.  Open up, insert VEX battery, screw screw into keps nut.  To attach to robot, use (2) 8-32 button head screws to screw into frame.

author: christelsayegh

title: Laminar Flow Fan plate
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a Fan control plate design for creating a more laminar/focused flow on a fans exhaust. (This isn't a fan cover :-))
The turbulence is reduced, providing for more controlled flow and pressure.
Curved blades generated less noise but at the expense of loss in performance caused by the fact that curved blades stall (turbulent air flow) at a lower static pressure than straight blades.
Similar design can be seen in Noctua NF-F12 fans and SilverStone Air Penetrator fans.
Check this video out from SilverStone to see the concept: http://youtu.be/8m8fC809TK0
I've printed the 92mm and 120mm versions, and they work.
This design works on curved edge fans that rotate in counter clockwise direction (about 99.9% of fans).
I haven’t measured the change in the P-Q curve, but would imagine it creates and entire new curve. 20-August: Added 40mm V4 plate. This is a little tricky to print, because of thinner blades. But the performance is more in-line with the others. I tested on Fan FD244010HB and only had a loss of flow of 2-4% with a gain in pressure from 15-20%.

I sliced with Cura in Repetier Host V1.0.2 without problems.
Plate should be mounted on the exhaust, with the letter Q facing out.

remixed_from.author: RockstarAlchemist
remixed_from.title: Snap Together Mini-lamp: Slicable and LED Power

description.text: A recreation of the snap together Luxo Jr lamp scaled up to be the maximum size possible on a 200mm x 200mm print bed.

I created this because the existing Luxo Jr models were not of a high enough resolution to scale up. When printed at larger sizes they had issues with the lamp bell not having enough facets to be be circular and also the design and tolerances not being tight enough to support the lamps weight. This design when printed at 1:1 scale has a base which almost completely fills a 200mm x 200mm print bed and the lamp should stand upright and be fairly rigid but adjustable.   
Please be aware the snap fittings are very very tight! This is deliberate as otherwise the lamp will be floppy. It's recommended that before attempting the large parts like the lamp bell and base  you first print the box sections, rods and hinges to make sure you can physically assemble them. I found holding the parts with a cloth and inserting them using a forceful twisting motion worked best. If you are really struggling to get the parts to snap together open up the holes using a cutting tool or change the design. I have included the Autocad 123D Design files for all the parts (except the upper links as I didn't need to recreate those) specifically so you can adjust them for your printer.  
The parts are reasonably simple to print but very time consuming as they are large. You shouldn't need supports apart from the lamp bell. I recommend you print fragile items such as the rods with a high percentage infill to make them strong.  
To finish the lamp off nicely you can fit springs and wire in an LED through the dedicated holes in the base and lamp bell. The hole in the very rear of the bell back is large enough to fit a typical star mounted LED inside, on the model shown in the photos I have mounted a star on a heatsink and glued the heatsink to the back. If you do decide to add an LED you could end up with a fully functioning lamp suitable for any desk, mine runs off a USB port :)

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/aGcOdOdOk85

This design is based heavily after a model I constructed while attending The Art Institute of Pittsburgh in 1993 for an advanced model making class. The original model was constructed of styrene sheets, acrylic, and "kit bashed" items from found model kits (photo attached of original model I built). The design I modeled here was constructed from memory of the original design. The details and size were very close. I printed this using translucent PLA filament, using rafts and support material. It may take some time to break the support material from the part. I used needle nose pliers to carefully remove the unwanted material. You may see some Robocop and Star Wars influence in the design. Displays nicely!

I printed this at standard resolution utilizing rafts and supports. Center the part, and make sure it is on the platform. It will take a couple of hours to print. Make sure you have enough filament on the spool. It should not require scaling, but check to be certain. Dimensions are 3.5"H x 2.87"W x 2.44"L

description.text: A printed version of the Frog for the RepRapPro.

This is my replacement of the Frog on the Reprappro model 3D printer. In my attempt to build this printer at home I found the laser cut wood parts a pain to get. Unlike earlier models of the Mendel this frog on this latest model is separated from the hot bead by a significant amount of open space so I have created a printed version of the frog to replace the laser cut part currently used. The other pieces used in the new replacement Frog are what I had laying around after my last Mendel build was completed. Pieces
12 5/16 Hex nuts
12 Lock washers 5/16
3 printed parts - bottom, middle and top plate.
2 threaded rod 5/16 230 mm long. Instructions:
Since the bottom and middle plates are separated by 15mm you can just put the two on the rod with nuts and lock washers end to end. The top plate is 63mm between the middle and top plate. Someone might want to add the bearing holders to the top and bottom plates but I left them off, one because I'd already printed the bearing holders and two because they can be a little delicate and if I broke one I didn't want to loose the whole plate. The holes for the washers are standard M3 and the nut dimensions are also M3 size compliant.

I recently started a modular synthesizer. Started with some modules from Doepfer, but I soon wanted more. It is modular, so I decided to build some modules myself. Some good ideas can be found on the Doepfer DIY (http://www.doepfer.de/DIY/a100_diy.htm). I started with some simple passive modules, a multiple, an OR gate and an AND gate. I ended with a Slew limiter and an Arduino Uno controlled module! The Arduino module is a VCO / Clock Divider / program it yourself. See it soon on my blog at jh-interact.blogspot.nl !

18 mg90s servos

diodes.

many m3 nuts and bolts
and very very little fingers to plug all wire together.

the code is the kurt's phoenix heavely modified
Pay attention, in my design all the legs are the same : no left and right design, you must invert rotation by code.

comments.text:
Hi Ferretti!
I'm also almost finished building this amazing hexapod of yours, with the same hardware, but I also have some issues with the code. Everything is working well at lower servo movement speeds, except when the speed is increased with PSB_PAD_RIGHT button, then the servo movements are not synchronized anymore with timings in the other part of the code I think and so the hexapod moves like a cat with ducktape sticked to its paws :) joke :). I also tried the delay that Shiul93 suggested, but no luck. At higher speeds movements are still far from smooth. Is there any chance to take a look at the code once again or if you maybe remember the default values that you changed in Phoenix_SSC32.h and Phoenix_input_PS2.h, or even if any of you guys figured out the solution for the smooth movement, I would really appreciate it :).

comments.text:
Just want to give a warning about MG90s servos from eBay. I got burned by buying them off eBay from China (seller x431shop).
Half of servos don't move, others make terrible noise and get stuck sometimes. I was able to get stuck ones moving again after I disassembled them and "relived pressure" by not tightening screws all the way. They still get stuck tho. So I ordered few from Amazon and these work great, so I'm now sure eBay ones were 100% fake and defective (visually you can't tell, except for horns are very tight on fake ones). So keep that in mind, and buy from reputable seller, or at least test them right away (I didn't touch them for months so it was too late to return).

author: Ferretti

description.text:
This is a clip on attachement to my wooden window blinds, it allows me to hangs a sheet to darken the room.
I have a projector and a screen, but the sun shines through the blinds degrading my viewing contrast during the day.  This allows a dark sheet to further block the sun without permanantly changing the blinds.
My contrast is much better, while still allowing me to easily open the windows.

Print 6 of them, or the plate file.  They press fit onto 2" x 0.1" wooden blinds.  I put mine on the top, bottom, and half way point on both side edges.  Then I cut a dark sheet 2" larger than the window on all sides, poked holes where the clips were, and attached to clips with mini zip-ties.  
As the blinds are raised, the sheet travels up with it and tri-folds, allowing most of the window to be opened for sunlight.  An iron can be used to set the fabric, and will improve your tri-fold action.

title: Objet Cartridge Transfuser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Are you tired of wasting the last 100g of resin because you can't reload an almost empty cartridge in the printer ? And what about the last 250g of cleaning solution ? We are, and we made this. Simply pop this device between two Objet 1Kg cartridges of resin, support or cleaner; and the top cartridge will safely empty in the bottom one, without exposing the contents to air or light. Works with all cartridges made for the :
Objet 24
Objet 30
Objet 30 Pro
Objet 30 Scholar Before each use
A. Soak in IPA (in an ultrasonic cleaner)
B. Let dry thoroughly After each use
A. Clean thoroughly with the Water jet (careful uncured resin and support are corrosive)
B. Soak in IPA (in an ultrasonic cleaner)
C. Let dry thoroughly Disclaimer: We are not responsible for any damage to your material or printer as a result of the use, and mis-use, of this device. This device is not an authorised device and might void your manufacturer warranty. Use at own risk.

• Print in glossy mode with the dividing plane firmly horizontal (auto placement puts it slanted)
  • Clean with the Water jet (this wont clear the pipes)
  • Clean with an ultrasonic cleaner using 10% Caustic Soda solution
  • Clean with the Water jet until water passes through the pipes unobstructed.
  • Clean with an ultrasonic cleaner using 10% Caustic Soda solution
  • Clean thoroughly with the Water jet to get every last bit of support out of the pipes.
  • Use a flat file to sharpen the tips as much as possible (otherwise it wont pass through the rubber)

comments.text: The thing is very slightly tilted forward, so the back two 'corners' of the 'cloth' are off the raft and this caused print failures - the trick is to tilt it back 0.4 of a degree, then slice a tiny sliver off the bottom using the 'divide' or 'split' option in your slicer software (I'm using Zortrax's Z-suite) then the raft or brim will form fully and this beautiful artefact will print :)

Lavalier Microphones (or "Lav's" in the hip street lingo) are great for picking up clean, isolated audio from a person.   
They work best when clipped onto a collar, lapel or other clothing parts I don't know the names of.  
They don't work so well on T-shirts. But I like T-shirts! So one day whilst filming our show we came up with this solution.  
1) Print object. I made several in base clothing colors like white, gray and black.  
2) Clip the lav onto the front portion with the microphone pointed up.  
3) Slide the clip onto the t-shirt neck (keep it centered so it stays straight) and loop the wire around the top.  
4) Become a STAR!

comments.text: Wonderful little clip, if a bit top-heavy - my actors needed to secure the wire to counterbalance it on shirts that were a little floppy.
comments.author: Willeth

description.text:
The initial idea was to create a 3D test-bed that would allow anyone with a printer to manufacture custom lab equipment suited for experiments that require a tool or sensor to move from point A to B. My project required that I mount a hall-effect sensor and scan the magnetic field of a rare earth magnet. For another project, I mounted a piezoelectric sensor on the head and used it for topographic scanning.
Other uses for the platform:
USB microscope examiner.
Automated pipetting. The goal of this project is to get people to make application-specific iterations and posting them!
The device isn't meant to be lab grade, but is definitely suited for high-school science projects.
All of my projects were done with an arduino and spare servos I had lying around.
My blog post that elaborates more on the magnetic field scanning:
http://www.nuclearfarnsworth.com/boldly-going-where-no-man-has-gone-before/
A video of the device working: http://youtu.be/zf2CvUZoLX8

Print out all of the parts, use bolts and nuts to secure everything together. The slots for the servos are rather loose and require hot glue. I did this so people wouldn't be limited to specific servos. If you want, the solidworks files should allow you to resize the slots and add bolt-holes.
A nice little pen cup. Compatible with most pen brands.
This is a cup holder, if your cup doesn't hold your cup size, just go into your sclicer and size it up ( or down if your cup is to loose)

Two-piece joint for self-assembly furniture.
Takes: #8-32 x 3/4 bolt with a round head + nut and four #8 countersunk wood screws
This watch consists of individual snap together links and a body file with an opening to fit a 1" press in clock face that you can buy online. Enjoy.

I printed all my pieces with a layer height of 0.2 mm, and between 40-50% infill rectilinear. Also your going to want to slow down your perimeters and infill by 5-15 mm/s to ensure the small features are printed precisely. No need to support anything. Rotate everything 90 degrees in the X direction in Repetier.
You're going to need a bunch of the "body link" pieces according to how big your wrist is.
You need one "clasp" to join the two sides of the band.
Then you need one "body piece" according to how large your clock face is. There are "1 inch clock faces" readily available at hobby stores, arts and craft stores or clock shops. I got mine local for $10. The hole size for a 1" clock face is actually 1 3/8" or 34.93 mm. My face was a bit smaller at 33.614 mm. I have included both. If you buy a clock face that specifically says "1 inch clock face" you will need v5, with the 34.93 mm face. If yours comes with no sizing like mine from the clock shop check to make sure what size you will need with some calipers.
Printed mine with a Printrbot Simple.
